cheatsheetvideos.quote: David Got help for his Class M using our Cheat sheet!
Jose explains how the motorcycle cheat sheet helped him pass his written exam.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to wobble, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep riding, as the wobble will likely correct itself.
questions.answerB: Quickly brake.
questions.answerC: Close the throttle to slow down.
questions.answerD: Accelerate quickly.
questions.explanation: Trying to accelerate out of a wobble will only increase the problem. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down while gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as you can, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Once off the road, you should address the problem causing the wobble.

questions.question: When stopping behind a vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop far behind the vehicle, then slowly creep up.
questions.answerB: Stay well behind the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Make a quick stop right behind the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Stay about four car lengths behind the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Stay well behind the vehicle in front of you, even if you are both stopped. The vehicle could back up unexpectedly, or you may need space to get out of the way of another vehicle bearing down on you from behind.

questions.question: If you are feeling tired while riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep going and hope to wake up.
questions.answerB: Ride faster.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Get off the road and rest.
questions.explanation: You should avoid riding if you are tired. When making a long trip, take rest breaks at least every two hours to reduce the risk of becoming fatigued.

questions.question: You should do a pre-ride inspection:
questions.answerA: Before every ride.
questions.answerB: About once every 10 rides.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Once a season.
questions.explanation: A small technical fault can have much more serious consequences on a motorcycle than on a car. To avoid these consequences, inspect your motorcycle before every ride.

questions.question: Riding directly alongside another vehicle is discouraged because:
questions.answerA: You may have a difficult time getting to a highway exit.
questions.answerB: You may be in the other vehicle’s blind spot.
questions.answerC: You may block the driver's view.
questions.answerD: It prevents other drivers from passing both of you.
questions.explanation: Riding alongside another vehicle is dangerous because you could be riding in the vehicle's blind spot. The driver may enter your lane without warning if they can't see you. The vehicle will also block your route of escape if a hazard arises.

questions.question: To increase your visibility, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn off your headlight during the day.
questions.answerB: Wear dark clothes.
questions.answerC: Keep your headlight on at all times.
questions.answerD: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Strategies for making yourself more visible include wearing brightly-colored and reflective clothing, keeping your headlight on at all times, and varying your lane position as conditions demand.

questions.question: Reflective clothing should:
questions.answerA: Be worn only at night.
questions.answerB: Be worn only during the day.
questions.answerC: Not be worn.
questions.answerD: Be worn day and night.
questions.explanation: Brightly-colored and/or reflective clothing will increase your chances of being seen under any conditions. Remember that most motorcycle crashes happen in broad daylight so it is still best to wear bright clothing during the day.

questions.question: If you are being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Kick it away.
questions.answerB: Stop until the animal loses interest.
questions.answerC: Swerve around the animal.
questions.answerD: Approach the animal slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles often seem to attract dogs. If you are being chased by a dog, downshift and approach it slowly. Then, as you approach the dog, accelerate and leave it behind.

questions.question: When a group of riders is passing another vehicle on a two-lane road, the riders should:
questions.answerA: Pass in pairs.
questions.answerB: Pass in a staggered formation with several riders passing at the same time.
questions.answerC: Pass one at a time.
questions.answerD: Avoid passing.
questions.explanation: When a group of motorcyclists is passing another vehicle on a two-lane road, the riders should pass the vehicle one at a time. Each motorcyclist should complete their pass before the next rider's pass begins.

questions.question: If in a no passing zone:
questions.answerA: A motorcycle may still pass another vehicle.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle is not allowed to pass another vehicle.
questions.answerC: A motorcycle may pass another vehicle if the pass can be completed before another vehicle approaches.
questions.answerD: A motorcycle may pass on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: Passing is prohibited in no passing zones. It is also prohibited to pass by riding off of the main-traveled portion of a roadway.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerB: Only protects your eyes.
questions.answerC: Protects more than just your eyes.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield helps protect your entire face, including your eyes. Goggles can protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either.

questions.question: When it comes to motorcycle safety, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume everything on your motorcycle will work properly.
questions.answerB: Conduct a pre-ride inspection before every ride.
questions.answerC: Conduct a pre-ride inspection each month.
questions.answerD: Conduct a pre-ride inspection twice a week.
questions.explanation: A small mechanical fault can have more serious consequences on a motorcycle than on a car. Conduct a thorough pre-ride inspection of your motorcycle before every ride.

questions.question: When operating a motorcycle on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride faster than usual.
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerD: Use only the rear brake.
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should reduce your speed. Make certain to use both brakes when braking and avoid making sudden moves.

questions.question: If it is warm outside, should you wear a leather jacket while riding?
questions.answerA: No, it will make you too hot.
questions.answerB: Yes, but take frequent breaks to remove the jacket and cool off.
questions.answerC: Yes, riding jackets are made to keep the rider cool, even in warm weather.
questions.answerD: No, jackets get in the way of steering.
questions.explanation: In warm weather, a riding jacket will help prevent dehydration in addition to serving the basic protective function that it provides at all times. Many jackets are designed to protect riders against overheating, even in warm weather.

questions.question: When riding behind a car, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in a position that will allow the other driver to see you in their rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Assume the driver sees you.
questions.answerC: Ride in the far left portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Ride in the far right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When riding behind a car, you should position yourself so you can be seen in the other driver's rearview mirror. Riding in the center portion of the lane will generally ensure that you will appear in the middle of their rearview mirror, where the driver is most likely to notice you.

questions.question: When crossing railroad tracks that are parallel to the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Cross the tracks at a 90-degree angle.
questions.answerB: Avoid crossing the tracks for any reason.
questions.answerC: Try to cross the tracks at a 45-degree angle.
questions.answerD: Slowly inch across the tracks.
questions.explanation: To safely cross railroad tracks, trolley tracks, or pavement seams running parallel to your lane, move to a lane position that will allow you to cross them at an angle of at least 45 degrees. Then, make a quick, sharp turn. If you try to edge across, the tracks or seam could catch your tires and throw you off balance.

questions.question: When riding in a group, you should:
questions.answerA: Never use a staggered formation.
questions.answerB: Place inexperienced riders at the back of the group.
questions.answerC: Not use your mirrors.
questions.answerD: Not tailgate other riders within the group.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, it is generally best to use a staggered formation. Use your mirrors periodically to check on riders behind you. Both the lead and sweep riders should be experienced motorcyclists who know group riding procedures well. Maintain proper space cushions within the group of riders.

questions.question: Smoothly downshifting on motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Is a useless action.
questions.answerB: Can allow the rider to engine brake.
questions.answerC: Is illegal.
questions.answerD: Should not be done if other vehicles are around.
questions.explanation: Engine braking by smoothly downshifting can be a useful option for motorcyclists. If you choose to engine brake, apply your brake lights separately to let other drivers know that you are slowing down.

questions.question: If you are preparing to pass another operator on the left, you should:
questions.answerA: Get into the right part of the lane so you can be seen in their side mirror.
questions.answerB: Get into the left part of the lane to increase your line of sight.
questions.answerC: Stay in the center part of the lane so you can be seen in their rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: Weave in your lane to draw attention to yourself.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, ride in the left portion of your lane to increase your line of sight and to make yourself more visible to any drivers in the passing lane. Use your mirrors and turn your head to check for traffic before changing lanes.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: The pass may be completed in a no passing zone.
questions.answerB: The rider may travel up to 10 mph over the speed limit to complete the pass.
questions.answerC: The pass must be started and completed within a passing zone.
questions.answerD: The pass must be completed on the shoulder, if one is present.
questions.explanation: Passing must be completed within the posted speed limits, and only in areas where passing is safe and legal.

questions.question: You will ______ hear a tire going flat.
questions.answerA: Always
questions.answerB: Usually
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: Seldom
questions.explanation: Motorcycle riders will rarely actually hear a tire going flat. Tire failure is more often indicated by a change in how the motorcycle handles.

questions.question: For the best protection, jackets and pants:
questions.answerA: Should cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.answerB: Should be loose and flap in the wind while you are riding.
questions.answerC: Should only partially cover your arms and legs.
questions.answerD: Should be made of wool.
questions.explanation: To provide adequate protection when riding, jackets and pants should cover your arms and legs completely. Your clothing should fit snugly but be loose enough to let you move freely. Leather or newer kinds of synthetic materials provide the best protection in the case of an accident.

questions.question: To be effective, a face shield should not:
questions.answerA: Be free of scratches.
questions.answerB: Allow clear views to both sides.
questions.answerC: Be airtight.
questions.answerD: Fasten securely.
questions.explanation: An effective face shield should be free of scratches, be resistant to penetration, allow clear views to both sides, fasten securely, permit air to pass through, and provide enough space for eyeglasses or sunglasses to be worn underneath. It is important for a face shield to permit the passage of air because an airtight face shield can create fogging and make it difficult for a rider to see.

questions.question: When preparing to pass a vehicle on the left, it is important to ride on the left side of your lane because:
questions.answerA: The right side could be slippery.
questions.answerB: It will give you the best chance of spotting hazards in the next lane.
questions.answerC: People don’t usually expect to be passed on their left.
questions.answerD: It will place you in the rearview mirror of the car in front of you.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. This lane position will increase your line of sight and make your more visible to oncoming traffic.

questions.question: What does this signal mean?
questions.answerA: Rest stop
questions.answerB: High beams on
questions.answerC: Turn right
questions.answerD: Hazard
questions.explanation: Signals are an important part of communication when riding in groups. When the lead rider's right leg is extended, it means there is a hazard in the roadway on their right side.

questions.question: To help provide space for drivers attempting to merge into your lane from an entrance ramp, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in your lane.
questions.answerB: Merge into the next lane, if possible.
questions.answerC: Not worry about it, since they are the ones trying to merge.
questions.answerD: Ride on the far left shoulder.
questions.explanation: Drivers merging onto a highway and into your lane may not notice your motorcycle. Give them plenty of space to safely merge by moving into a different lane, if you can.

questions.question: Compared to riding during the day, a motorcycle operator who is riding at night should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Ride more slowly.
questions.answerB: Allow more space between their motorcycle and other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Use their high beam whenever possible.
questions.answerD: Tailgate other vehicles.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: Riding between two vehicles moving in the same direction:
questions.answerA: Is illegal.
questions.answerB: Is encouraged if traffic is heavy.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged during the day to prevent traffic jams.
questions.answerD: Is acceptable if the motorcyclist is comfortable with the move.
questions.explanation: In Oregon, it is illegal for motorcycles and mopeds to pass between two moving vehicles on a multilane highway or one-way street.

questions.question: Where is the throttle usually located?
questions.answerA: Near the left footrest
questions.answerB: Near the right footrest
questions.answerC: On the left handle grip
questions.answerD: On the right handle grip
questions.explanation: The throttle of a motorcycle is usually located on the right handle grip. Be sure to know where all of your motorcycle's controls are located before riding.

questions.question: Helmets are:
questions.answerA: Required for all motorcycle passengers.
questions.answerB: Not required, but recommended.
questions.answerC: Only required for passengers under the age of 21.
questions.answerD: Only required for passengers who do not have their own motorcycle license.
questions.explanation: Oregon law requires all motorcycle operators and passengers to wear a U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT)-approved helmet while riding.

questions.question: When being passed, do not move into the portion of the lane farthest from the passing vehicle because:
questions.answerA: The passing vehicle may re-enter your lane too early.
questions.answerB: You may prevent another vehicle from passing you.
questions.answerC: The portion of the lane nearest the passing vehicle is better.
questions.answerD: You are more likely to experience a wind blast from the passing vehicle on the far side of the lane.
questions.explanation: When being passed, you should not ride on the side of your lane that is farthest from the passing vehicle. Doing so may tempt the driver to return to your lane before there is actually room for them to do so safely.

questions.question: To adjust for added weight when riding with a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Operate at a slower speed than usual.
questions.answerB: Maintain a shorter following distance that you would if riding without a passenger.
questions.answerC: Operate at a faster speed than usual.
questions.answerD: Brake a little later than you would if riding without a passenger.
questions.explanation: The extra weight of a passenger means that your motorcycle will need more time than usual to speed up, slow down, and turn. To accommodate the added weight, you should reduce your speed; start slowing earlier than normal; increase your following distance; and seek out larger gaps when crossing, entering, or merging with traffic.

questions.question: What does this hand signal mean?
questions.answerA: Slow or stop
questions.answerB: Left turn
questions.answerC: Right turn
questions.answerD: Backing up
questions.explanation: Instead of or in addition to mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing downward, it means the operator plans to slow down or stop.

questions.question: When following a car, usually the best portion of the lane to ride in is:
questions.answerA: The left portion.
questions.answerB: The center portion.
questions.answerC: The right portion.
questions.answerD: The left or right portions.
questions.explanation: When riding behind a passenger vehicle, it is usually best to ride in the center of the lane so you will be visible in the driver's rearview mirror. Most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than their side mirrors, so this lane position will increase your chances of being seen.

questions.question: When may you not need to increase your following distance?
questions.answerA: When the road is slippery
questions.answerB: When there is a lot of traffic
questions.answerC: When you can see through the vehicle in front of you
questions.answerD: When it is raining
questions.explanation: An increased following distance is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a longer following distance.

questions.question: You should increase your following distance if:
questions.answerA: The pavement is dry.
questions.answerB: The pavement is wet.
questions.answerC: You can see through the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.answerD: The sun is out.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a larger following distance.

questions.question: A danger of riding next to a row of parked cars is:
questions.answerA: You may not find a parking spot.
questions.answerB: A driver may unexpectedly pull out from the row into your path.
questions.answerC: Others may be driving slowly while looking for a parking spot.
questions.answerD: The road may be uneven.
questions.explanation: Riding next to parked cars presents a number of potential dangers. A driver might pull out of parking space and into your path without looking. Car doors may be opened into your lane and pedestrians may step out from between cars.

questions.question: If a tire goes flat while riding and you must stop, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Relax on the handgrips.
questions.answerB: Shift your weight toward the good tire.
questions.answerC: Brake on the good tire and steer to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes and stop quickly.
questions.explanation: If one of your tires fails, hold the handgrips firmly and begin to slow down by easing off the throttle while maintaining a straight course. If you must brake, gradually apply the brake of the tire that is still good, if you are sure of which tire that is. Edge toward the side of the road as you slow down, squeeze the clutch, and stop.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Use your high beam.
questions.answerB: Use the headlights of vehicles ahead to help you see.
questions.answerC: Be visible.
questions.answerD: Ride only in the left portion of your lane.
questions.explanation: When riding at night, use your high beam (unless you are following or meeting another car), take advantage of the headlights of other vehicles, and wear reflective materials to increase your visibility. You should always be flexible about your lane position, selecting whichever position will help you to see, be seen, and have an adequate space cushion.

questions.question: How often should a motorcycle operator check their mirrors?
questions.answerA: Never
questions.answerB: Occasionally
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: More often than the amount time spent looking ahead
questions.explanation: It is recommended that you frequently check your mirrors to be aware of potential hazards behind you.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a possible cause of a wobble on your motorcycle?
questions.answerA: Incorrect tire pressure
questions.answerB: Improper loading
questions.answerC: Unsuitable accessories
questions.answerD: Uneven road
questions.explanation: Most wobbles can be traced to improper loading, unsuitable accessories, or incorrect tire pressure. Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble.

questions.question: If you must stop quickly in a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Straighten up, square the handlebars, and stop.
questions.answerB: Abruptly apply both brakes while leaning.
questions.answerC: Apply only the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Apply only the front brake.
questions.explanation: If you must stop quickly while in a curve, you should first straighten and square the handlebars, then stop. If straightening your motorcycle is not possible, you should apply the brakes smoothly and gradually, reduce your lean angle, then increase the brake pressure as you slow down.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a way to prevent a friend from driving while intoxicated?
questions.answerA: Arrange a safe ride home for them.
questions.answerB: Get them involved in activities to slow their drinking and keep them busy while they sober up.
questions.answerC: Make them wait 15 minutes after their last drink before driving.
questions.answerD: Get other friends involved in stopping your friend from driving.
questions.explanation: To prevent someone from drinking and driving, it is a good idea to arrange an alternative way for them to get home, involve them in other activities to slow the pace of their drinking, use any available excuse to keep them from leaving, and recruit friends to help apply peer pressure.

questions.question: In Oregon, riding in pairs is:
questions.answerA: Illegal.
questions.answerB: Illegal when other vehicles are near.
questions.answerC: Allowed, but not recommended.
questions.answerD: Allowed, but should only be done if there is a lot of traffic.
questions.explanation: In Oregon, it is legal for motorcycles to ride two abreast in a single lane. However, this can be unsafe and is not recommended.

questions.question: An advantage to keeping a cushion of space between your motorcycle and other vehicles is that:
questions.answerA: You can pass danger more quickly.
questions.answerB: You will have a more narrow view of the road so you can stay focused.
questions.answerC: You will have more time to react to the movements of others.
questions.answerD: You can more easily follow the path of the next vehicle.
questions.explanation: Maintaining a cushion of space between your motorcycle and other vehicles on the road will give you a clearer view of any emerging hazards, more time to react to hazards, and more space to maneuver around them.

questions.question: Clothing made of which type of material can offer the best protection to motorcyclists?
questions.answerA: Leather
questions.answerB: Wool
questions.answerC: Polyester
questions.answerD: Silk
questions.explanation: Leather garments can provide the greatest level of protection to motorcyclists. It is important to wear clothing that covers your legs and arms entirely when riding a motorcycle.

questions.question: To stop quickly, you should:
questions.answerA: Rely only on the front brake.
questions.answerB: Rely only on the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Use the front brake and then the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: If you need to stop quickly, you should apply both brakes at the same time.

questions.question: When riding in curves, turning, or entering a highway, the best group formation is:
questions.answerA: Pairs.
questions.answerB: Single-file.
questions.answerC: Staggered.
questions.answerD: Passing.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is generally the best option when traveling in a group, riders should move into a single-file line through curves, through turns, and when entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: To avoid fatigue, you should ride for no more than:
questions.answerA: Two hours in a day.
questions.answerB: Four hours in a day.
questions.answerC: Six hours in a day.
questions.answerD: 10 hours in a day.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of fatigue, limit yourself to only about six hours of riding per day. Stop regularly to rest when making a long trip.

questions.question: You’ll have a better chance of avoiding serious injury if you wear all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: A DOT-approved helmet.
questions.answerB: Face or eye protection.
questions.answerC: Ear buds.
questions.answerD: Protective clothing.
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: Motorcycles must have all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: A white license plate light.
questions.answerB: A minimum of one red brake light.
questions.answerC: A blue reflector on the rear.
questions.answerD: A horn.
questions.explanation: In Oregon, motorcycles are required to have between one and three white headlights; at least one red taillight; one white license plate light; at least one red brake light; amber turn signal lights (if the motorcycle was built after 1972); a red reflector on the rear; at least one rearview mirror; a horn; fenders on all wheels; at least one brake; and an exhaust system in good working order. All lighting must be U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT)-compliant.

questions.question: If riding a three-wheel motorcycle in a group, you should travel in a:
questions.answerA: Staggered formation.
questions.answerB: Pyramid formation.
questions.answerC: Single-file line.
questions.answerD: Row of pairs.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is usually best for a group of two-wheeled motorcycles, three-wheeled motorcycles are too wide to allow this formation. A group of riders on three-wheeled motorcycles should travel in a single-file line.

questions.question: An advantage to keeping the size of a group of riders small is:
questions.answerA: A small group is less easily separated in traffic than a larger group.
questions.answerB: A small group can disregard traffic laws to stay together.
questions.answerC: Riders will always be trying to catch up to the group.
questions.answerD: It will be difficult to keep track of where everyone is.
questions.explanation: There are several advantages to keeping groups of riders small. In comparison to a large group, a small group is easier for other vehicles to pass safely, is less likely to get separated by traffic or stop lights, and creates less need for slower riders to hurry to catch up to the rest of the group.

questions.question: When riding on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Make sudden moves.
questions.answerC: Move to the edge of the road.
questions.answerD: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.explanation: Strategies for safe riding on slippery surfaces include reducing your speed, avoiding sudden moves, staying away from the edge of the road, and riding in the tire tracks left by other cars.

questions.question: The effects of marijuana consumption can last for:
questions.answerA: No more than 15 minutes.
questions.answerB: About an hour.
questions.answerC: About two hours.
questions.answerD: More than six hours.
questions.explanation: When marijuana is smoked, it can begin to affect the smoker within minutes and effects can last for between two and four hours. When marijuana is eaten, it may take over an hour to begin to affect the consumer, but the effects of the marijuana may last for more than six hours.

questions.question: If you lock the rear tire on a good traction surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Release and re-apply the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Keep it locked until you completely stop.
questions.answerC: Release the rear brake and only use the front brake.
questions.answerD: Release the rear brake and use both brakes to stop.
questions.explanation: If you accidentally lock the rear brake on a good traction surface, you can keep it locked until you have completely stopped. You should still be able to steer your motorcycle with a locked rear wheel.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride within a foot of the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerB: Wear dark clothing.
questions.answerC: Signal only when you feel like it.
questions.answerD: Stay alert and be prepared to act to avoid a crash.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: When riding over rough surfaces, you should:
questions.answerA: Hold the handgrips loosely to allow for movement.
questions.answerB: Hold the handgrips firmly to maintain control.
questions.answerC: Use lots of throttle to help you get over the rough surface.
questions.answerD: Ride without a helmet as the helmet could become loose and cover your face.
questions.explanation: When riding over a rough surface, hold onto the handgrips firmly to ensure that you will maintain directional control over your motorcycle.

questions.question: When using a motorcycle with which you are unfamiliar, you should:
questions.answerA: Test the seat to make sure it is comfortable.
questions.answerB: Assume the motorcycle is in good riding condition.
questions.answerC: Work the throttle, clutch, and brakes a few times before riding.
questions.answerD: Ride as you usually do, since most bikes are similar.
questions.explanation: Since all motorcycles are somewhat different, you should be very careful when using one that is new to you. Familiarize yourself with the motorcycle before setting off. Learn the gear pattern before riding by working the throttle, clutch, and brakes a few times.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerA: In the front of the group.
questions.answerB: Just behind the leader.
questions.answerC: Close to the back of the group.
questions.answerD: At the tail end of the group.
questions.explanation: In a group of motorcyclists, less experienced riders should be positioned toward the front, just behind the leader. This ensures that they will not have to chase after the rest of the group. This positioning also allows them to be watched from behind by more experienced riders.

questions.question: If carrying a load in a sidecar, the motorcycle's stopping distance:
questions.answerA: May be increased.
questions.answerB: May be decreased.
questions.answerC: Is not a concern.
questions.answerD: Will be similar to the stopping distance of a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Because adding a load to a motorcycle increases its weight, the vehicle's inertia may increase, causing its stopping distance to increase. Begin slowing and stopping earlier when riding a motorcycle with a load or passenger in its sidecar.

questions.question: Taking a turn too fast:
questions.answerA: Is acceptable as long as you stay under the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Is safer on a motorcycle than in a car.
questions.answerC: Is acceptable as long as no vehicles are near you.
questions.answerD: Can cause you to end up in another lane or leave the road.
questions.explanation: Taking a turn too fast is dangerous. If you cannot hold the turn, you may end up turning into another lane or even off of the road entirely. Use caution when taking a turn.

questions.question: When approaching a blind intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the portion of the lane that will bring you into other drivers' fields of vision at the earliest possible moment.
questions.answerB: Always be in the left lane to be the farthest from oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Slowly sneak up to the intersection.
questions.answerD: Weave slightly in your lane so your headlight has a better chance of being spotted.
questions.explanation: When approaching a blind intersection, move into the part of the lane that will bring you into an oncoming driver's field of vision at the earliest possible moment. For example, when approaching a blind corner to your right, you may be seen sooner if you are in the left portion of your lane and not in the center portion.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked cars, a motorcycle operator should be prepared for:
questions.answerA: Open parking spaces.
questions.answerB: A motorist to unexpectedly pull out of a parking space and into traffic.
questions.answerC: Parking meters.
questions.answerD: Other motorists to see the motorcycle and stay out of its way.
questions.explanation: When passing a row of parked cars, a motorcyclist should be prepared for a parked car to suddenly pull out of a parking space and into traffic. It is often safest for a motorcyclist to ride in the left portion of their lane when passing a row of parked cars on their right to create the most possible space between their motorcycle and any potential hazards.

questions.question: Taking corners too fast:
questions.answerA: Can cause the rider to go into another lane.
questions.answerB: Is better than going too slowly.
questions.answerC: Often causes the rider to stay in their lane.
questions.answerD: Is acceptable because motorcycles are smaller than other types of vehicles.
questions.explanation: Taking a corner too fast may cause you to cross into another lane or go off the road. Be sure to decelerate before beginning to take a turn or curve.

questions.question: If you are hit by a wind blast caused by a passing vehicle, you will have the most room for error if you are riding:
questions.answerA: In the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: In the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: In the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder.
questions.explanation: If you are in the middle portion of your lane, you will have the greatest room for error if your control is disrupted by a wind blast from a passing vehicle.

questions.question: Engine braking:
questions.answerA: Is illegal.
questions.answerB: Is slowing down by turning the engine off.
questions.answerC: Is slowing down by downshifting.
questions.answerD: Is not encouraged because of the damage it does to the engine.
questions.explanation: Shifting to a lower gear produces an effect similar to applying the brakes. This is known as engine braking.

questions.question: Riding with a passenger:
questions.answerA: Usually results in no difference in handling a motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Is usually safe for beginning riders.
questions.answerC: Can affect the handling of a motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Is encouraged to get operators used to different riding situations.
questions.explanation: A passenger puts extra weight on a motorcycle, which causes the motorcycle to handle differently. Only experienced riders should carry passengers.

questions.question: When riding, a cushion of space is helpful to:
questions.answerA: Give you space to react to hazards.
questions.answerB: Hide you from other drivers.
questions.answerC: Prevent you from avoiding hazards.
questions.answerD: Allow you to look at road signs.
questions.explanation: Allowing a cushion of space around your motorcycle at all times will help ensure that you will have time to react if another driver makes a mistake. You will need the space to maneuver safely.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, you should look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: How can you increase your ability to be seen at an intersection?
questions.answerA: Try to make eye contact with other drivers.
questions.answerB: Make sure you always ride using your headlight.
questions.answerC: Wave your arms.
questions.answerD: Ride closely to vehicles in front of you.
questions.explanation: To maximize your ability to be seen at an intersection, ride with your headlight on and select a lane position that provides oncoming traffic with the best view of your motorcycle. Maintain a space cushion that allows you enough space to take evasive action if a hazard arises. You should never assume that making eye contact with a driver will be enough to make them consciously register your presence.

questions.question: Can clothing help prevent injuries in the event of a crash?
questions.answerA: No, clothing is not really for protection.
questions.answerB: No, clothing is more of a personal choice.
questions.answerC: Yes, but only if garments are very loose and flap in the wind.
questions.answerD: Yes, if pants and a jacket cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.explanation: Appropriate clothing can reduce the risk of injury in a crash. Choose a jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs, are made of sturdy material, and are snug enough that they do not flap in the wind.

questions.question: When choosing clothes for riding, which of the following is not a good choice?
questions.answerA: A jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs completely
questions.answerB: Boots or shoes that cover your ankles
questions.answerC: Gloves made of leather
questions.answerD: A baseball cap to cover your hair
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: When you have mounted your motorcycle, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Make sure the mirrors are clean.
questions.answerB: Make sure the horn works.
questions.answerC: Close the fuel supply valve.
questions.answerD: Make sure the clutch works smoothly.
questions.explanation: After mounting your motorcycle, you should make sure the clutch, throttle, horn, and brakes all work properly. Clean and adjust the mirrors and make sure that the fuel supply valve is open.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerB: Avoid other drivers' blind spots.
questions.answerC: Avoid surface hazards.
questions.answerD: Prevent access to an escape route.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: When looking through a turn to see where you are going, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn just your head.
questions.answerB: Turn your head and shoulders.
questions.answerC: Turn just your shoulders.
questions.answerD: Turn your entire body.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn only your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: Motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Do not have blind spots because of their small size.
questions.answerB: Have blind spots, but they are so small they should not cause concern.
questions.answerC: Have blind spots that should be routinely checked.
questions.answerD: Are too small to have blind spots.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like any other vehicle. Always turn your head to check your blind spot before changing lanes. Head checks should be a regular part of your scanning routine.

questions.question: The front brake is:
questions.answerA: Safe, if used properly.
questions.answerB: Safe, even if used improperly.
questions.answerC: Only to be used if the rear brake fails.
questions.answerD: Not to be used regularly.
questions.explanation: The front brake is safe to use as long as it is used properly. The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake, providing at least three-fourths of the total stopping power.

questions.question: An adequate cushion of space between your motorcycle and other vehicles:
questions.answerA: Allows you time to react if another driver makes a mistake.
questions.answerB: Keeps you in a single area of the lane, limiting your movement.
questions.answerC: Allows you to rely on others to identify hazards.
questions.answerD: Requires you go faster to stay with traffic.
questions.explanation: Maintaining a cushion of space on all sides of your motorcycle helps to ensure that you have time and space to react if another road user makes a mistake.

questions.question: If taking a long trip, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to minimize the number of rest breaks.
questions.answerB: Use artificial stimulants, like caffeine, if you feel drowsy.
questions.answerC: Dress warmly to avoid getting too cold during the ride.
questions.answerD: Schedule more than 12 hours of riding a day.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of fatigue on a long trip, dress to protect yourself from tiring elements, such as wind, cold, and rain. Limit yourself to no more than six hours of riding per day and take rest brakes at least every two hours. Avoid using artificial stimulants, as these only result in extreme fatigue when they wear off.

questions.question: The best lane position is:
questions.answerA: The one that lets you travel the fastest.
questions.answerB: The one that allows you to draft off of other vehicles.
questions.answerC: The one that allows you be seen by other motorists.
questions.answerD: The one that places you in other vehicles’ blind spots.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise. Choose a lane position that maximizes your space cushion.

questions.question: Which of the following provides a rider with the best protection?
questions.answerA: Goggles
questions.answerB: A face shield
questions.answerC: A windshield
questions.answerD: Eyeglasses
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield provides protection for your entire face in the event of a crash. Goggles will protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield or eyeglasses are not a substitute for either goggles or a face shield.

questions.question: Most motorcycle crashes happen:
questions.answerA: On short trips.
questions.answerB: On long trips.
questions.answerC: After at least an hour of riding.
questions.answerD: After more than 8 hours of riding.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen on trips shorter than five miles, just a few minutes after the rider starts out.

questions.question: The gearshift lever is operated by:
questions.answerA: Your right hand.
questions.answerB: Your right foot.
questions.answerC: Your left hand.
questions.answerD: Your left foot.
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever of a motorcycle is located in front of the left footrest and is operated by the rider's left foot.

questions.question: The front brake is:
questions.answerA: Too dangerous to be used by inexperienced operators.
questions.answerB: Best when used by itself.
questions.answerC: Meant to occasionally assist the rear brake.
questions.answerD: To be used with the rear brake.
questions.explanation: Use both the front and rear brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: Your lane position should not:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see.
questions.answerB: Avoid placing you in other drivers' blind spots.
questions.answerC: Encourage other drivers to share your lane.
questions.answerD: Provide you with an escape route.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: The front brake supplies how much of a motorcycle's potential stopping power?
questions.answerA: About 25 percent
questions.answerB: About 50 percent
questions.answerC: About 70 percent
questions.answerD: 100 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake and can provide at least 70 percent of the motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: If another driver is following you too closely, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Not worry about them.
questions.answerB: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.answerD: Get off the roadway.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Increasing your speed may only encourage the driver to tailgate you at a higher speed.

questions.question: A motorcyclist is well-protected if they are wearing:
questions.answerA: A jacket that allows the arms to be exposed.
questions.answerB: Boots with tall heels.
questions.answerC: Leather gloves.
questions.answerD: Shoes that stop below their ankle.
questions.explanation: For your protection while riding, it is best to wear a jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs completely. Boots or shoes should be tall and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Footwear should have low heels that will not catch on the foot pegs or rough road surfaces. Gloves made of leather or another durable material will help protect your hands in the event of a crash while providing you with an improved grip on the controls.

questions.question: Long-term exposure to wind noise:
questions.answerA: Is recommended.
questions.answerB: Can cause hearing loss.
questions.answerC: Is not harmful.
questions.answerD: Is less damaging than listening to music.
questions.explanation: Long-term exposure to wind noise while riding can cause hearing damage, even if you wear a helmet. Use of proper hearing protection is recommended to prevent damage.

questions.question: Brightly-colored helmets:
questions.answerA: May make it easier for the wearer to be seen.
questions.answerB: Can be distracting.
questions.answerC: Don’t help to improve a rider's visibility.
questions.answerD: Are not permitted.
questions.explanation: Choosing a brightly-colored helmet is recommended. Not only will the helmet protect you in the case of a crash, but the bright color of the helmet will help other road users see you.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Always avoid the left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: Always avoid the right portion of a lane.
questions.answerC: Always avoid the center portion of a lane.
questions.answerD: Use whichever portion of the lane is safest.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that you always need to avoid. Adjust your position in response to changing conditions on the road.

questions.question: The faster you drink:
questions.answerA: The more the alcohol will accumulate in your body.
questions.answerB: The faster the alcohol is removed from your body.
questions.answerC: The more minimal the effects of the alcohol will be.
questions.answerD: The more likely you will be able to evade being pulled over.
questions.explanation: The faster you drink, the more alcohol will accumulate in your body. It is never safe to operate a motor vehicle after drinking alcohol in any amount.

questions.question: When exiting a highway while riding in a group, which riding formation should be used?
questions.answerA: Staggered
questions.answerB: Single-file
questions.answerC: Paired up
questions.answerD: Riding three across a lane
questions.explanation: While a staggered formation is usually best for group riding, a group should switch into a single-file formation when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: Most crashes occur during the day. To lessen the chance of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Wear darkly-colored clothing.
questions.answerB: Wear brightly-colored clothing.
questions.answerC: Not ride during the day.
questions.answerD: Look for safer routes.
questions.explanation: To minimize your chances of being in a crash, you should make yourself as visible as possible by wearing brightly-colored clothing when riding, even during the day.

questions.question: Use a turn signal:
questions.answerA: When you’re planning to increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Only when there is a lot of traffic.
questions.answerC: Any time you plan on changing lanes.
questions.answerD: Only if it is dark outside.
questions.explanation: You should use a turn signal every time you plan to turn or change lanes, even if you think no one else is around to see it.

questions.question: When approaching an uneven surface, such as a bump or pothole, you should rise slightly off of your seat:
questions.answerA: So you can jump off the motorcycle if you need to.
questions.answerB: So your legs can absorb the shock.
questions.answerC: So other drivers can see you better.
questions.answerD: So you can get a better view of the uneven surface.
questions.explanation: When riding over an uneven surface, rising off of your seat will allow your joints to absorb some of the force of impact. This will make it less likely that the impact of the surface will throw you off of the motorcycle.

questions.question: Motorcyclists riding in a group should avoid pairing up because:
questions.answerA: A merging driver may not see both riders.
questions.answerB: Reflections from both helmets may make it difficult for the riders to see.
questions.answerC: Riding in pairs does not allow riders the necessary space to maneuver.
questions.answerD: It is too difficult for riders on the left side of a pairing to exit a highway.
questions.explanation: When traveling in a group, it is never recommended for motorcyclists to ride in pairs. Neither rider will have adequate room to maneuver to avoid hazards.

questions.question: When you are being passed from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Ride in any portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When you are being passed from behind, stay in the center portion of your lane. This will discourage the other driver from re-entering your lane before it is safe.

questions.question: A motorcycle operator can slow down by:
questions.answerA: Downshifting.
questions.answerB: Upshfting.
questions.answerC: Cross-shifting.
questions.answerD: Rolling on the throttle.
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists often slow down by simply downshifting. Motorcyclists should be aware that slowing down in this manner does not activate the brake lights.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: It is a good idea to drag your feet.
questions.answerB: Your toes should be pointed downward.
questions.answerC: You should keep your feet firmly on the footrests.
questions.answerD: You should try to keep your feet away from the controls.
questions.explanation: To maintain proper balance, your feet should be placed firmly on the footrests and not dragged on the ground. Do not point your toes downward, as this may cause them to catch on the road. Keep your feet near the controls so you can reach them quickly, if needed.

questions.question: When riding in fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your high beam headlight.
questions.answerB: Use your low beam headlight.
questions.answerC: Use no lights.
questions.answerD: Alternate between the low and high beams.
questions.explanation: You should use your low beam headlight when riding in foggy conditions. Do not use your high beams when riding near other vehicles.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield protects the wearer from:
questions.answerA: Insects.
questions.answerB: Headlight glare.
questions.answerC: Noise.
questions.answerD: Sunshine.
questions.explanation: In addition to protecting your face from injury in a crash, a face shield protects you from wind, dust, dirt, rain, insects, and pebbles thrown up from surrounding vehicles.

questions.question: You have been drinking alcohol. If you wait an hour for each drink before riding your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: You cannot be arrested for drinking and riding.
questions.answerB: Your riding skills will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Side effects from the drinking may still remain.
questions.answerD: You will be okay as long as you ride slowly.
questions.explanation: On average, the body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. However, some alcohol may accumulate in the body even if a person consumes only one drink per hour. Their abilities and judgment can still be impaired.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should tell them to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Get on the motorcycle after the engine has been started.
questions.answerB: Sit as far forward as they can without crowding you.
questions.answerC: Hold firmly onto your waist, hips, or belt.
questions.answerD: Feel free to talk whenever they want.
questions.explanation: To help keep the operator focused on riding, passengers should avoid unnecessary conversation or movement. Passengers should get on a motorcycle only after the engine has been started. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator and hold firmly onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: A helmet will not provide the best possible protection:
questions.answerA: If it is certified by the DOT.
questions.answerB: If it fits snugly.
questions.answerC: If it is free of defects.
questions.answerD: If it has cracks.
questions.explanation: A helmet should meet U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards and fit snugly all the way around to provide maximum protection. It should be free of defects such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: Where should a load be placed?
questions.answerA: As low as possible
questions.answerB: As high as possible
questions.answerC: Behind the rear axle
questions.answerD: On one side of the motorcycle
questions.explanation: Loads should kept low, either fastened securely or in saddlebags. Piling loads against a sissy bar or frame on the back of a seat is dangerous because it can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and change the balance of the motorcycle. Loads should be equally distributed on both sides of the motorcycle.

questions.question: Usually, a good way to handle tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerB: Come to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Speed up to put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerD: Ignore them.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by causing them to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger or cargo:
questions.answerA: It may take less time to accelerate, but more time to stop.
questions.answerB: It may take more time to accelerate and stop.
questions.answerC: It may take more time to accelerate, but less time to stop.
questions.answerD: It may take less time to accelerate and stop.
questions.explanation: Because of the additional weight added by cargo or a passenger, motorcycles may take longer to accelerate and stop than they would if only transporting the operator.

questions.question: When riding downhill on a motorcycle with a sidecar:
questions.answerA: Stopping will be easier than when riding without a sidecar.
questions.answerB: Stopping will take longer than when riding without a sidecar.
questions.answerC: You cannot stop.
questions.answerD: Stopping is about as easy as it is when riding without the sidecar.
questions.explanation: Riding with a sidecar increases the weight of a motorcycle and increases the braking force needed to stop the motorcycle. Slowing and stopping take longer when riding a vehicle downhill than when riding on a flat surface.

questions.question: In general, the body gets rid of almost ______ per hour.
questions.answerA: One drink
questions.answerB: Two drinks
questions.answerC: Three drinks
questions.answerD: Four drinks
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Signal, use your mirrors, and turn your head.
questions.answerB: Signal and use your mirrors.
questions.answerC: Turn your head and change lanes.
questions.answerD: Signal and change lanes.
questions.explanation: Always use the proper turn signal before a turn or lane change. Use your mirrors and perform head checks before changing lanes to check for traffic surrounding your vehicle.

questions.question: Switching to a lower gear is also known as:
questions.answerA: Engine braking.
questions.answerB: Acceleration.
questions.answerC: Upshifting.
questions.answerD: Coasting.
questions.explanation: Shifting to a lower gear causes an effect similar to using the brakes. For this reason, downshifting is also known as engine braking.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of protective riding gear?
questions.answerA: A leather jacket
questions.answerB: Boots that go above the ankle
questions.answerC: Hearing protection
questions.answerD: Pants made of a soft material
questions.explanation: Appropriate protective gear for motorcycling includes a jacket and pants made of leather or another sturdy material; footwear that covers and supports your ankles; and hearing protection, even if you wear a helmet.

questions.question: Since most crashes happen during daylight hours, you should:
questions.answerA: Not ride during the day.
questions.answerB: Wear bright clothing all the time.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder and stay out of traffic.
questions.answerD: Wear dark clothing all the time.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen in broad daylight. You should always wear brightly-colored clothing when riding to maximize your chances of being seen, even during the day.

questions.question: When approaching a blind intersection with a stop sign, riders should:
questions.answerA: Stop at the stop sign then proceed through the intersection.
questions.answerB: Ignore the stop sign and move forward to get a better look.
questions.answerC: Stop at the stop sign before moving forward to improve their view of cross traffic.
questions.answerD: Proceed through the intersection without stopping.
questions.explanation: When approaching a blind intersection that is controlled by a stop line or stop sign, you must first stop where indicated. You may then edge forward and stop again just short of where the cross traffic lane meets your lane. From that position, lean your body forward and look around buildings, parked cars, or bushes to see if anything is approaching. Make sure your front wheel stays out of the crossroad while you are looking.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle, you should ride in the left portion of your lane because:
questions.answerA: It increases your line of sight.
questions.answerB: It decreases your line of sight.
questions.answerC: It makes it difficult to see beyond the vehicle.
questions.answerD: It allows the other driver to speed up.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane, both to increase your line of sight and to make yourself more visible to drivers already in the passing lane.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Be visible to other drivers.
questions.answerB: Keep your intentions unknown from other drivers.
questions.answerC: Always stay within a foot of another vehicle.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: Studies show that when motorcycles have their headlights turned on during the day:
questions.answerA: They are not as easy to see as other vehicles.
questions.answerB: They are more visible to other drivers than when their headlights are turned off.
questions.answerC: Other drivers are often confused.
questions.answerD: They are less safe than when their headlights are turned off.
questions.explanation: The best way to help other drivers see your motorcycle is to keep your headlight on whenever you ride. During the day, a motorcycle with its headlight on is twice as likely to be noticed.

questions.question: Your lane position should:
questions.answerA: Avoid other road users' blind spots.
questions.answerB: Provide a good view of the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Provide a poor view of road hazards.
questions.answerD: Invite others to share your lane.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should help you to see others and be seen by them. Avoid riding in another driver's blind spot for a long period of time.

questions.question: When riding, the best protection for an operator is:
questions.answerA: A cushion of space between their vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.answerB: A good leather jacket.
questions.answerC: Sturdy boots.
questions.answerD: A good understanding of motorcycle laws.
questions.explanation: Your first and best protection against collisions with other vehicles is simply to keep your distance from them. The only way to be sure you will have enough time to react to mistakes made by other drivers is to leave plenty of space between you and the vehicles around you. Wearing proper gear is also important when riding a motorcycle.

questions.question: At a minimum, how often should a motorcycle's hydraulic fluid be checked?
questions.answerA: Once a day
questions.answerB: Once a week
questions.answerC: Once a year
questions.answerD: Before every ride
questions.explanation: Pre-ride motorcycle inspections are an important part of ensuring safe riding. Hydraulic fluids and coolants should be checked at least once a week.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should:
questions.answerA: Only take a few minutes.
questions.answerB: Take more than an hour.
questions.answerC: Be complicated to perform.
questions.answerD: Not be done before every ride.
questions.explanation: It is important to do a thorough inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. This will usually take you only a few minutes.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerB: Happen at night.
questions.answerC: Are caused by worn tires.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have ridden their motorcycles for less than six months.
questions.explanation: Always take extra care when riding a new or unfamiliar motorcycle. Most crashes involve riders who have had less than six months of experience with the motorcycle that they are using.

questions.question: Keep an expanded cushion of space between your motorcycle and the vehicle in front of you:
questions.answerA: When conditions will make stopping more difficult than usual.
questions.answerB: When you want to look at the scenery.
questions.answerC: To encourage other drivers to cut you off.
questions.answerD: To prevent the driver in front of you from knowing you are there.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a larger following distance.

questions.question: When riding at night you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerC: Use the vehicle in front of you to help see.
questions.answerD: Wear tinted glasses.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: During the day, you should:
questions.answerA: Not ride with your headlight on.
questions.answerB: Ride with your headlight on, but only if it is cloudy.
questions.answerC: Always ride with your headlight on.
questions.answerD: Use your headlight if you think it helps.
questions.explanation: You should always have your headlight on when riding, even during the day. This can make you twice as likely to be noticed by other drivers.

questions.question: If either tire goes flat while riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Roll on the throttle.
questions.answerB: Hold the handle grips loosely.
questions.answerC: Gently apply the brake of the non-flat tire.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed to exit the road more quickly.
questions.explanation: If one of your tires goes flat while you are riding, you should ease off the throttle and maintain a straight course as you slow down. If you must brake, gradually apply the brake of the tire that is not flat, if you are certain of which tire that is.

questions.question: An experienced rider:
questions.answerA: Changes positions within their lane as conditions change.
questions.answerB: Stays in one portion of a lane at all times.
questions.answerC: Weaves within the lane to be more visible.
questions.answerD: Travels only on the oily portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Unlike drivers of larger vehicles, a motorcyclist has three lane position options in their travel lane. The rider should select whichever position is safest based on road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: Riding on the far side of a lane when following another vehicle:
questions.answerA: Is recommended because you will be seen easily.
questions.answerB: Is not recommended because drivers seldom use their side mirrors and may not see you.
questions.answerC: Is recommended because a passenger in the vehicle may tell the driver that you are there.
questions.answerD: Is illegal because you have to ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Most drivers do not look at their side mirrors as often as they look at their rearview mirror. Therefore, when following a car, it is generally best to ride in the center portion of the lane where you are most likely to be visible in the driver's rearview mirror.

questions.question: In New Hampshire, a person who is age 21 or older with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of ______ is considered legally intoxicated.
questions.answerA: 0.02 percent
questions.answerB: 0.04 percent
questions.answerC: 0.06 percent
questions.answerD: 0.08 percent
questions.explanation: A person who is of legal drinking age with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher is considered legally intoxicated. It is both illegal and unsafe to ride a motorcycle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: Which of the following does not offer protection to a motorcycle rider?
questions.answerA: A leather jacket
questions.answerB: Boots that go over the ankle
questions.answerC: A baseball cap that fits snugly
questions.answerD: Gloves
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: When you are riding on a bridge grating, you should:
questions.answerA: Always ride on the far right side of the lane.
questions.answerB: Always ride on the far left side of the lane.
questions.answerC: Slowly zigzag across the grating.
questions.answerD: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the surface.
questions.explanation: Crossing rain grooves or bridge gratings may cause your motorcycle to move in a weaving motion. This is usually not dangerous, so simply relax and proceed across the surface at a steady speed. Trying to ride at an angle to compensate for the weave is dangerous because it forces you to zigzag to stay in your lane.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good way for a rider to increase their visibility?
questions.answerA: Wearing proper clothing
questions.answerB: Using their headlight at all times
questions.answerC: Using their turn signals
questions.answerD: Waving at other drivers
questions.explanation: To make yourself visible to other road users, you should wear brightly-colored clothing with reflective materials, use your headlight at all times, and use your signals and brake light properly.

questions.question: When loading cargo onto a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Pack heavier items in front of the tank bag.
questions.answerB: Pack lighter items near the front.
questions.answerC: Try to not place items over the rear axle.
questions.answerD: Place items behind the rear axle.
questions.explanation: Heavier items should be loaded in front of the tank bag. You should try to place the load over or in front of the rear axle. Putting the load behind the rear axle may affect your control.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a benefit of riding in a close group?
questions.answerA: It takes up minimal space on the highway.
questions.answerB: The group is easy to see.
questions.answerC: The group is unlikely to be split up.
questions.answerD: The riders will get to their destination more quickly in a close group than a group that is spread out.
questions.explanation: Riding in close ranks is recommended over riding in a group that is spread out because the group will take up less space on the road, be easier for others to see, and be less likely to get separated at traffic lights and during passes.

questions.question: Why should you use both the front and rear brakes every time you slow or stop?
questions.answerA: Using only one brake will cause the brakes to wear unevenly.
questions.answerB: It develops good braking habits for emergency situations.
questions.answerC: Using both brakes is the only way to slow down a motorcycle.
questions.answerD: The brakes only work when both are applied.
questions.explanation: Using both brakes even in normal stopping stops will help you develop the habit of always using both. Having this habit will serve you well in emergencies, where using both brakes may be critical.

questions.question: When crossing angled railroad tracks, it is usually safest to approach the tracks:
questions.answerA: By proceeding straight within your lane.
questions.answerB: At a 45-degree angle.
questions.answerC: At a 90-degree angle.
questions.answerD: At a fast speed.
questions.explanation: In general, it is safest to simply proceed straight in your lane when crossing angled railroad tracks. Turning to approach tracks at a right angle can be dangerous because it may send you traveling into another lane.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerB: Only protects your eyes.
questions.answerC: Helps protect your whole face.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield can help protect your whole face in a crash. While goggles can protect your eyes, they won't protect the rest of your face. A windshield is not a substitute for a face shield or goggles.

questions.question: Several factors influence blood alcohol concentration (BAC). Which of the following does not play a role?
questions.answerA: The amount of alcohol consumed
questions.answerB: How fast a person drinks
questions.answerC: Body weight
questions.answerD: Height
questions.explanation: There are several major factors that can affect a person's blood alcohol concentration (BAC). A BAC is determined in part by the amount of alcohol someone has consumed, how fast they consumed the alcohol, and their body weight.

questions.question: If attempting to brake in a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake more gradually than you would on a straightaway.
questions.answerB: Brake as hard as you would on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: Wait until you are not in the curve to brake.
questions.answerD: Only use the rear brake.
questions.explanation: Because tires have less traction when a motorcycle is leaning than when it is upright, always try to position your motorcycle in an upright position before braking. If you must brake while in a curve, apply the brakes more smoothly and gradually than if your motorcycle was traveling on a straightaway.

questions.question: When making normal stops, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerD: Alternate between the front and rear brakes.
questions.explanation: Make it a habit to always use both brakes when slowing or stopping, even for normal, non-emergency stops.

questions.question: When a vehicle attempts to pass you from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Move to the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Move to the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Move to the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Not be concerned about which portion of the lane you are using.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally best to ride in the center portion of your lane. Being too close to the passing vehicle increases the risk of a collision.

questions.question: In which of the following situations should you increase your following distance?
questions.answerA: Traffic is light.
questions.answerB: Traffic is heavy.
questions.answerC: You are able to see the roadway through vehicles in front of you.
questions.answerD: There is pleasant and clear weather.
questions.explanation: While a two-second following distance is generally adequate, you should increase your following distance any time conditions would require a longer stopping distance, such as when the pavement is slippery due to poor weather conditions. Additionally, you should increase your following distance at night, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead, and when traffic is heavy.

questions.question: When riding through a curve, a group of motorcyclists should:
questions.answerA: Ride in a staggered formation.
questions.answerB: Ride in a single-file formation.
questions.answerC: Ride in a side-by-side formation.
questions.answerD: Use both lanes if possible.
questions.explanation: While a staggered formation is generally recommended, riders in a group should move into a single-file formation when taking curves, taking turns, entering a highway, or leaving a highway.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look where you are going.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go by turning only your head. Keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance while turning. Your arms should be slightly bent any time you are holding the handgrips.

questions.question: If hazards are on your left, you should ride:
questions.answerA: In the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: In the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: In any portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder.
questions.explanation: When hazards exist to your left, it is often best to ride in the right portion of the lane. Be prepared to adjust your lane position as road and traffic conditions change.
