questions.explanation: Passes must be completed within posted speed limits. Only pass where it is safe and legal to do so.

questions.question: When riding at night, how should your following distance compare to your following distance during the day?
questions.answerA: You should allow a longer following distance when following another vehicle at night.
questions.answerB: You should allow a shorter following distance when following another vehicle at night.
questions.answerC: You should always maintain the same following distance regardless of the time of day.
questions.answerD: Following distance really doesn’t matter.
questions.explanation: Distances are difficult to judge in the dark because visual cues (like shadows and light contrasts) can be missing or distorted. You should allow a longer following distance when riding at night than you do when riding during the day.

questions.question: A potential danger of braking too hard is:
questions.answerA: Losing traction on one or both wheels.
questions.answerB: Coming to a complete stop before you expect to.
questions.answerC: Popping a tire.
questions.answerD: Taking too long to stop.
questions.explanation: If you over-apply your brakes, you may lose traction on one or both wheels and crash.

questions.question: How can you discourage another vehicle from sharing your lane?
questions.answerA: Ride in the middle of your lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of your lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Swerve from side to side in your lane.
questions.explanation: To discourage automobile drivers from trying to share your lane, ride in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: Most crashes occur in broad daylight. To be more visible, you should:
questions.answerA: Wear brightly-colored clothing.
questions.answerB: Wear darkly-clothing.
questions.answerC: Ride without your headlight.
questions.answerD: Ride in a weaving pattern.
questions.explanation: Because most crashes happen in broad daylight, you should always wear brightly-colored clothing while riding, even during the day.

questions.question: If a driver is following you too closely, you should:
questions.answerA: Flash your brake light before you slow to warn the other driver.
questions.answerB: Accelerate.
questions.answerC: Pull over to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Slow down.
questions.explanation: If someone is following you too closely, it is a good idea to flash your brake light before slowing down. A tailgater may be concentrating on you and not see upcoming hazards that require traffic to slow down.

questions.question: How can a motorcycle operator discourage lane sharing by other drivers?
questions.answerA: By giving dirty looks to other drivers
questions.answerB: By riding in the center portion of the lane
questions.answerC: By riding in the left portion of the lane
questions.answerD: By riding in a zigzag pattern
questions.explanation: By riding in the center portion of your lane, you will ensure that there is not a large space on either side of your motorcycle. Minimizing those spaces can help deter drivers from trying to share the lane with you.

questions.question: Reflective clothing should:
questions.answerA: Be worn only at night.
questions.answerB: Be worn only during the day.
questions.answerC: Not be worn.
questions.answerD: Be worn day and night.
questions.explanation: Brightly-colored and/or reflective clothing will increase your chances of being seen under any conditions. Remember that most motorcycle crashes happen in broad daylight so it is still best to wear bright clothing during the day.

questions.question: Maximum front-line braking is accomplished by:
questions.answerA: Using the rear brake only.
questions.answerB: Using the front brake only.
questions.answerC: Using both brakes.
questions.answerD: Using the rear brake while downshifting.
questions.explanation: Maximum straight-line braking is accomplished by fully applying both the front and rear brakes without locking either wheel. You should always use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: A three-wheeled motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Handles curves about the same as a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Handles curves differently than a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Should not be operated in curves.
questions.answerD: Should use the shoulder when taking a curve.
questions.explanation: The cornering characteristics of a three-wheeled motorcycle or a motorcycle with a sidecar differ from those of a two-wheeled motorcycle.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should be done:
questions.answerA: Before every ride.
questions.answerB: Once a week.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Twice a month.
questions.explanation: Perform an inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. This takes only a few minutes and helps prevent dangerous situations before entering traffic.

questions.question: What is the best lane position for a motorcycle operator?
questions.answerA: The left position in the lane
questions.answerB: The center position in the lane
questions.answerC: The right position in the lane
questions.answerD: There is no single lane position that is best for all situations.
questions.explanation: There is no lane position that is always best and no lane position that should always be avoided. Select a lane position that is appropriate for your current riding conditions, allowing you to maintain an adequate space cushion and be visible to others.

questions.question: Motorcycle windshields:
questions.answerA: Are a good substitute for a face shield.
questions.answerB: Are a good substitute for goggles.
questions.answerC: Will not protect your eyes from the wind.
questions.answerD: Do not protect against items thrown from other vehicles.
questions.explanation: A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either a face shield or goggles. Most windshields will not protect your eyes from the wind.

questions.question: The best lane position is:
questions.answerA: The one that lets you travel the fastest.
questions.answerB: The one that allows you to draft off of other vehicles.
questions.answerC: The one that allows you be seen by other motorists.
questions.answerD: The one that places you in other vehicles’ blind spots.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise. Choose a lane position that maximizes your space cushion.

questions.question: Which portion of the lane should be avoided?
questions.answerA: The left portion of the lane
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane
questions.answerD: No portion of the lane should always be avoided.
questions.explanation: There is no lane position that is always best and no lane position that should always be avoided. Select a lane position that is appropriate for riding conditions.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Always avoid the left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: Always avoid the right portion of a lane.
questions.answerC: Always avoid the center portion of a lane.
questions.answerD: Use whichever portion of the lane is safest.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that you always need to avoid. Adjust your position in response to changing conditions on the road.

questions.question: When riding near stopped or slow-moving cars, a motorcyclist should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and wait until traffic begins to move.
questions.answerB: Ride on the shoulder to get through the area as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Weave between the cars to get through the area as quickly as possible.
questions.answerD: Not weave between the cars.
questions.explanation: Riding between slowed or parked cars can leave you vulnerable to unexpected hazards, such as opening car doors or cars suddenly pulling into traffic. If a hazard arises, you will not have room to safely maneuver. Never travel on the shoulder of a road because other drivers will never expect you to be there.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride slower than the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and the brakes.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerD: Pull in the clutch when turning.
questions.explanation: To help reduce your reaction time, you should cover the clutch and brakes. This is especially helpful when riding through areas where potential hazards are likely.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Signal, use your mirrors, and turn your head.
questions.answerB: Signal and use your mirrors.
questions.answerC: Turn your head and change lanes.
questions.answerD: Signal and change lanes.
questions.explanation: Always use the proper turn signal before a turn or lane change. Use your mirrors and perform head checks before changing lanes to check for traffic surrounding your vehicle.

questions.question: Head and neck injuries can be reduced by:
questions.answerA: Wearing a helmet.
questions.answerB: Wearing a leather jacket.
questions.answerC: Using the rear brake only.
questions.answerD: Wearing goggles.
questions.explanation: The risk of head and neck injuries is greatly reduced by wearing a high-quality helmet. A helmet is a rider's best defense against injury in the case of an accident.

questions.question: When entering a highway or curve, motorcyclists riding in a group should:
questions.answerA: Ride single-file.
questions.answerB: Ride in a staggered formation.
questions.answerC: Ride in pairs.
questions.answerD: Ride in the far right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: While a staggered group formation is usually best, it is better to switch to a single-file formation when turning, taking curves, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: Riding gloves are often:
questions.answerA: Made of leather.
questions.answerB: Made of wool.
questions.answerC: Not pre-curved.
questions.answerD: Unsafe for the rider.
questions.explanation: Gloves designed for motorcycle riding are usually made of leather. In addition to improving your grip, gloves provide protection for a rider's hands and fingers.

questions.question: The middle portion of the lane usually contains an oily strip. You should:
questions.answerA: Try to avoid the oily strip when it is raining.
questions.answerB: Ride only on the oily strip, as it provides increased traction.
questions.answerC: Avoid the entire center portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Not worry about oil or other items in a lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks build up in the center of each lane. Unless the road is wet, this strip usually still provides enough traction more a motorcycle to operate safely. The strip is generally narrow enough that you can ride to either side of it and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: To increase your line of sight when preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the left portion of your lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the right portion of your lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the center portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Try to stand up on your motorcycle.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. This will increase your line of sight and make you more visible to oncoming traffic.

questions.question: When downshifting, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift through multiple gears at a time.
questions.answerB: Shift through one gear at a time.
questions.answerC: Always shift all the way down to neutral first.
questions.answerD: Accelerate.
questions.explanation: When shifting into a lower gear, shift down one gear at a time and ease out the clutch through the friction zone between each downshift.

questions.question: Riding at night is usually:
questions.answerA: Easier than riding during the day because you can more easily see the lights of other vehicles.
questions.answerB: More difficult than riding during the day because it is harder to see.
questions.answerC: Not allowed on highways.
questions.answerD: Less distracting than riding during the day.
questions.explanation: Riding safely at night is challenging because it is harder to see and be seen than it is during the day. The absence of normal shadows and light contrasts makes it harder to judge distances.

questions.question: When exiting a highway while riding in a group, which riding formation should be used?
questions.answerA: Staggered
questions.answerB: Single-file
questions.answerC: Paired up
questions.answerD: Riding three across a lane
questions.explanation: While a staggered formation is usually best for group riding, a group should switch into a single-file formation when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: If your rear wheel locks while braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Release the brake until the rear tire regains traction, then re-apply the brake.
questions.answerB: Release the brake and only engage the front brake.
questions.answerC: Keep it locked until the motorcycle comes to a stop.
questions.answerD: Release the brake and coast to a stop.
questions.explanation: If your rear wheel locks while braking, do not release the brake. Instead, keep it locked until you come to a full stop.

questions.question: If a tire goes flat while riding and you must stop, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Relax on the handgrips.
questions.answerB: Shift your weight toward the good tire.
questions.answerC: Brake on the good tire and steer to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes and stop quickly.
questions.explanation: If one of your tires fails, hold the handgrips firmly and begin to slow down by easing off the throttle while maintaining a straight course. If you must brake, gradually apply the brake of the tire that is still good, if you are sure of which tire that is. Edge toward the side of the road as you slow down, squeeze the clutch, and stop.

questions.question: Where is the engine cut-off switch usually located?
questions.answerA: Near the left handgrip
questions.answerB: Near the right handgrip
questions.answerC: Near the left footrest
questions.answerD: Near the right footrest
questions.explanation: The engine cut-off switch is generally located next to the right handgrip. It is important to know where all of your motorcycle's controls are located before starting out.

questions.question: When it is raining, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Pull off to the side of the road until the rain stops.
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: Wet pavement is especially slippery when it first begins to rain. Deposits of oil left by cars will not yet have washed off the roadway. If it is raining, it is safest to ride in the tire tracks left by cars. The left tire track will often be your best choice, although this may vary.

questions.question: Fatigue can be increased by:
questions.answerA: Stopping frequently.
questions.answerB: Riding in cool weather.
questions.answerC: Being comfortable during your ride.
questions.answerD: Starting a ride late in the day.
questions.explanation: To reduce the danger of fatigue when riding, dress to protect yourself against tiring weather conditions, such as wind and rain. Limit yourself to no more than about six hours of riding per day and stop for a break at least once every two hours. Avoid taking artificial stimulants since you may experience extreme fatigue when they start to wear off.

questions.question: To increase your visibility, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn off your headlight during the day.
questions.answerB: Wear dark clothes.
questions.answerC: Keep your headlight on at all times.
questions.answerD: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Strategies for making yourself more visible include wearing brightly-colored and reflective clothing, keeping your headlight on at all times, and varying your lane position as conditions demand.

questions.question: Reflective clothing should:
questions.answerA: Be worn at night.
questions.answerB: Not be worn during the day
questions.answerC: Never be worn.
questions.answerD: Not be worn at night.
questions.explanation: Wear reflective materials to increase your visibility, especially when riding at night. Brightly-colored clothing with reflective materials will make you more visible to other road users.

questions.question: Drivers on an entrance ramp may not see you on the highway. What should you do to help an entering driver merge safely?
questions.answerA: Stay in your lane, as it is not your responsibility to be seen.
questions.answerB: Change to a lane away from the entrance ramp, if possible.
questions.answerC: Move to the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Weave within your lane to be more obvious to the entering driver.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision, always allow merging vehicles plenty of space to safely enter traffic. Change lanes away from the entrance ramp if there is room to do so safely. If there isn't another lane available, adjust your speed to open up space for the merging driver.

questions.question: What should you do to maintain proper control of your motorcycle while turning?
questions.answerA: Increase your speed before entering the turn.
questions.answerB: Keep the motorcycle from leaning.
questions.answerC: Look through the turn to anticipate the best course of action.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop before entering the turn.
questions.explanation: To maintain directional control through a turn, you should look through the turn by turning only your head. Slow down before turning and lean your motorcycle in the appropriate direction.

questions.question: On a slippery surface, you should not:
questions.answerA: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: Avoid making sudden moves.
questions.answerC: Use only the front brake when slowing or stopping.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes when slowing or stopping.
questions.explanation: To ride safely on a slippery surface, you should use both brakes when slowing or stopping, reduce your speed, and avoid making sudden moves. Be alert to oily areas, dirt, gravel, shaded areas, and bridges, as these surfaces are more likely to be slippery than others.

questions.question: What does this hand signal mean?
questions.answerA: Slow or stop
questions.answerB: Left turn
questions.answerC: Right turn
questions.answerD: Backing up
questions.explanation: Instead of or in addition to mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing upward, it means the operator plans to turn right or change lanes to the right.

questions.question: What can help reduce the risk of a head or neck injury in the event of a crash?
questions.answerA: Riding on the shoulder
questions.answerB: Riding under the speed limit
questions.answerC: Wearing a helmet
questions.answerD: Not allowing a passenger on the motorcycle
questions.explanation: Wearing a helmet is the single most effective thing you can do to reduce the risk of head or neck injuries in the event of a crash.

questions.question: When you have mounted your motorcycle, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Make sure the mirrors are clean.
questions.answerB: Make sure the horn works.
questions.answerC: Close the fuel supply valve.
questions.answerD: Make sure the clutch works smoothly.
questions.explanation: After mounting your motorcycle, you should make sure the clutch, throttle, horn, and brakes all work properly. Clean and adjust the mirrors and make sure that the fuel supply valve is open.

questions.question: It is difficult for other motorists to see motorcycles at night. To make up for that, a motorcycle rider should:
questions.answerA: Reduce their speed when riding at night.
questions.answerB: Sound their horn repeatedly when riding at night.
questions.answerC: Not ride at night.
questions.answerD: Stay directly in front of another vehicle to be seen in their headlights when riding at night.
questions.explanation: Strategies for safely riding at night include reducing your speed, increasing your following distance, using the lights of the car ahead to help see farther down the road, using your high beam headlight (unless following or meeting another vehicle), and being flexible about your lane position.

questions.question: To provide the best protection to the wearer, boots or shoes should:
questions.answerA: Be made of a soft material.
questions.answerB: Have long laces that are not tucked in.
questions.answerC: Cover the ankle and provide support.
questions.answerD: Have tall heels.
questions.explanation: For riding, choose boots or heavy shoes that are tall and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Heels should be low so that they won't catch on rough surfaces. Tuck in long laces so that they don't catch on the motorcycle's moving parts.

questions.question: When riding in a group, the best riding formation is generally:
questions.answerA: Pairs.
questions.answerB: A staggered formation.
questions.answerC: A single-file line.
questions.answerD: A pyramid formation.
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is generally best when riding in a group. You should move into a single-file line when turning, riding in a curve, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: If you are riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings and your motorcycle begins to weave, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake suddenly.
questions.answerB: Steer in a weaving pattern.
questions.answerC: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the grooves.
questions.answerD: Move to the leftmost portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle may weave while riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings, but this is generally not dangerous. If your motorcycle begins to weave, simply relax and proceed straight ahead at a steady speed. Trying to ride in a zigzag pattern to compensate for the weave will only increase the hazard.

questions.question: Riding directly alongside another vehicle:
questions.answerA: Can place you in the driver's blind spot.
questions.answerB: Is better than riding behind the other vehicle.
questions.answerC: Is safe because it limits your escape routes.
questions.answerD: Should only be done during the day.
questions.explanation: Avoid riding directly alongside another vehicle, since this may place you in the vehicle's blind spot. If the driver can't see you, they may enter your lane without warning. Riding alongside a vehicle is also dangerous because the vehicle will block your route of escape if a hazard arises.

questions.question: During the day, your headlight should:
questions.answerA: Not be used.
questions.answerB: Be used on its high beam setting.
questions.answerC: Be used on its low beam setting.
questions.answerD: Alternate between high beam and low beam settings.
questions.explanation: Using your high beam headlight during the day increases the likelihood that other drivers will see you. Use your high beam headlight any time you are not riding behind or approaching other vehicles.

questions.question: Before mounting the motorcycle, your pre-ride inspection should include all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: A tire check.
questions.answerB: A taillight test.
questions.answerC: A headlight test.
questions.answerD: A paint check.
questions.explanation: A pre-ride inspection should include checks of the tires, oil and fluids, lights, signals, clutch, throttle, mirrors, brakes, and horn. Conduct a thorough pre-ride inspection before every ride.

questions.question: A driver making eye contact with you:
questions.answerA: Means that they see you.
questions.answerB: Will never happen.
questions.answerC: Does not mean that they will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: Guarantees that they will properly yield to you.
questions.explanation: You should never count on eye contact to guarantee that a driver will yield to you. It is not uncommon for drivers to look directly at a motorcyclist but fail to consciously notice them.

questions.question: When selecting a helmet, make sure it is all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Designed to meet U.S. Department of Transportation standards.
questions.answerB: Snug.
questions.answerC: Defect-free.
questions.answerD: Attractive.
questions.explanation: You should select a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation and state standards; fits snugly all the way around; and has no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: An advantage to keeping a cushion of space between your motorcycle and other vehicles is that:
questions.answerA: You can pass danger more quickly.
questions.answerB: You will have a more narrow view of the road so you can stay focused.
questions.answerC: You will have more time to react to the movements of others.
questions.answerD: You can more easily follow the path of the next vehicle.
questions.explanation: Maintaining a cushion of space between your motorcycle and other vehicles on the road will give you a clearer view of any emerging hazards, more time to react to hazards, and more space to maneuver around them.

questions.question: Motorcycle headlights are:
questions.answerA: Usually more powerful than a car’s headlights.
questions.answerB: Usually just as powerful as a car’s headlights.
questions.answerC: Usually not as powerful as a car’s headlights.
questions.answerD: Usually larger than a car’s headlights.
questions.explanation: Motorcycle headlights are generally smaller and less powerful than those of cars.

questions.question: The proper body position on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Allows you to sit far enough forward that your arms will be slightly bent when holding the handle grips.
questions.answerB: Allows you to sit as far back as possible and have to stretch when trying to reach the handle grips.
questions.answerC: Makes you lean over the bike, requiring your arms to hold you up.
questions.answerD: Allows for your knees to be kept far from the gas tank.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should sit far enough forward that your arms will be slightly bent when holding the handle grips. This will permit you to easily and comfortably reach and operate the controls.

questions.question: Motorcycle riders:
questions.answerA: Should wear hearing protection at all times to prevent hearing damage.
questions.answerB: Should only wear hearing protection during long rides.
questions.answerC: Should not wear hearing protection because it will muffle other noises, such as horns and sirens.
questions.answerD: Do not need to use hearing protection if they are using a helmet.
questions.explanation: Longterm exposure to wind and engine noise can cause permanent hearing damage, even if the rider is wearing a full-face helmet. Wearing ear plugs or other hearing protection can guard against damage while still allowing the wearer to hear important sounds like horns and sirens.

questions.question: When consumed together, the effects of alcohol and drugs:
questions.answerA: Can be more pronounced than when either is consumed alone.
questions.answerB: Are less dangerous than when either is consumed alone.
questions.answerC: Are usually minimal.
questions.answerD: Often balance out.
questions.explanation: Many drugs, including prescription and over-the-counter medications, can impair your ability to ride safely. Some medications become even more dangerous when combined with alcohol.

questions.question: When riding, the best sitting position:
questions.answerA: Requires your arms be used to hold you up.
questions.answerB: Allows you to easily reach the controls.
questions.answerC: Keeps your arms straight when reaching the handle grips.
questions.answerD: Keeps your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should be seated in a posture that allows you to use your arms to steer rather than to hold yourself up. You should not have to stretch to reach the handgrips and your arms should be slightly bent when holding them. You should keep your knees against the gas tank to maintain your balance.

questions.question: When riding over rough surfaces, you should:
questions.answerA: Hold the handgrips loosely to allow for movement.
questions.answerB: Hold the handgrips firmly to maintain control.
questions.answerC: Use lots of throttle to help you get over the rough surface.
questions.answerD: Ride without a helmet as the helmet could become loose and cover your face.
questions.explanation: When riding over a rough surface, hold onto the handgrips firmly to ensure that you will maintain directional control over your motorcycle.

questions.question: When going through a turn on a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your eyes focused close to the front of the motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Look through the turn to where you want to go.
questions.answerC: Turn your entire body to see through the turn.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed before the turn.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, you should look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: Your motorcycle’s brake light is:
questions.answerA: More noticeable than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerB: Less noticeable than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerC: Less important than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerD: More easily seen than a car’s brake lights.
questions.explanation: The brake light of a motorcycle is usually not as noticeable as the brake lights of a car. Flashing your brake light before slowing or stopping can help other drivers notice that you are about to brake.

questions.question: During acceleration, a sidecar attached to a motorcycle will:
questions.answerA: Feel like it is lagging behind.
questions.answerB: Feel like it is accelerating faster than the motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Vibrate uncontrollably.
questions.answerD: Make acceleration seem faster.
questions.explanation: A sidecar is essentially an unpowered mass attached to the side of your motorcycle. Due to its inertia, it will feel like it is lagging behind when you accelerate.

questions.question: A motorcyclist can discourage other vehicles from lane sharing by:
questions.answerA: Riding in the left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: Riding in the center portion of a lane.
questions.answerC: Giving dirty looks if another driver moves into their lane.
questions.answerD: Riding in a zigzag pattern to fill up a lane.
questions.explanation: Any time a driver may be tempted to try to squeeze into your lane next to you, ride in the center portion of the lane to discourage them from doing so.

questions.question: ____ can remove alcohol and its effects from your body.
questions.answerA: Time
questions.answerB: Coffee
questions.answerC: Exercise
questions.answerD: Fresh air
questions.explanation: The only method that effectively reduces your BAC is not drinking alcohol for a period of time. Coffee, exercise, fresh air, and cold showers cannot reduce your BAC or change the effects of alcohol. They can help you remain awake, but they cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: When riding in a group, what does it mean when the lead rider raises their left arm and extends their index finger, as shown in the image?
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerB: Slow down.
questions.answerC: Ride in a single-file formation.
questions.answerD: The group will pull off at the next exit.
questions.explanation: Hand signals are an important part of communication when riding in groups. A lead rider raising their left arm and extending their index finger means that the group of riders should move into a single-file formation.

questions.question: A motorcycle needs:
questions.answerA: Less frequent attention than a car.
questions.answerB: More frequent attention than a car.
questions.answerC: To have pre-ride checks performed only by a mechanic.
questions.answerD: To be serviced only at a dealer.
questions.explanation: Because a small technical fault can have more serious consequences on a motorcycle than on a car, motorcycles need to be checked more frequently. Complete a thorough check before every ride.

questions.question: What can you do to increase your chances of being seen at an intersection?
questions.answerA: Ride while using your headlight.
questions.answerB: Swerve within your lane to draw attention to your motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Raise your arms.
questions.answerD: Avoid using your brakes.
questions.explanation: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, use your headlight and ride in a lane position that creates the best view of oncoming traffic. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle that allows you to take evasive action.

questions.question: Without a helmet, a motorcycle rider is ________ more likely to suffer a critical head injury in a crash.
questions.answerA: Three times
questions.answerB: Four times
questions.answerC: Five times
questions.answerD: Six times
questions.explanation: Without a helmet, a rider is five times more likely to sustain a critical head injury in a crash.

questions.question: When riding with a heavy load, you will want to adjust the:
questions.answerA: Brakes.
questions.answerB: Seat.
questions.answerC: Suspension.
questions.answerD: Brake light.
questions.explanation: Before riding with a heavy load, you should make sure your tire pressure, spring pre-load, air shocks, and dampers are at the settings recommended for the relevant weight.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not considered protective clothing?
questions.answerA: A leather jacket
questions.answerB: Full-fingered gloves
questions.answerC: Long pants made of denim
questions.answerD: Athletic shoes
questions.explanation: In the event of a fall, a motorcyclist can receive protection from a leather jacket, long pants made of heavy denim, and full-fingered gloves. It is best for a motorcyclist to wear lace-up boots, high-top boots, or heavy shoes that support their ankles.

questions.question: The single most important thing you can do to improve your chances of surviving a crash is to:
questions.answerA: Wear a high-quality helmet that is securely fastened.
questions.answerB: Wear shorts.
questions.answerC: Wear sneakers.
questions.answerD: Wear goggles.
questions.explanation: The single most effective action you can take to improve your chances of surviving a crash is to wear a high-quality helmet that is securely fastened.

questions.question: If drinking alcohol, you should:
questions.answerA: Decide if you are still fit to ride based on how you feel after you finish drinking.
questions.answerB: Set a limit beforehand so you can still safely ride.
questions.answerC: Not ride.
questions.answerD: Not be concerned about your riding abilities if you feel fine.
questions.explanation: The surest way to avoid the risks of riding under the influence of alcohol is to not ride after you have been drinking. Any amount of alcohol can impair your abilities.

questions.question: Your lane position should not:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see.
questions.answerB: Avoid placing you in other drivers' blind spots.
questions.answerC: Encourage other drivers to share your lane.
questions.answerD: Provide you with an escape route.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: If you are not traveling slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, the:
questions.answerA: Motorcycle could lurch and the rear tire could skid.
questions.answerB: Motorcycle could accelerate too quickly.
questions.answerC: Front tire will likely skid.
questions.answerD: Engine will make a loud noise.
questions.explanation: If you are not riding slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, the motorcycle will lurch and the rear wheel may skid.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should tell them to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Get on the motorcycle after the engine has been started.
questions.answerB: Sit as far forward as they can without crowding you.
questions.answerC: Hold firmly onto your waist, hips, or belt.
questions.answerD: Feel free to talk whenever they want.
questions.explanation: To help keep the operator focused on riding, passengers should avoid unnecessary conversation or movement. Passengers should get on a motorcycle only after the engine has been started. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator and hold firmly onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: An integrated braking system:
questions.answerA: Applies partial rear braking when the front brake is applied.
questions.answerB: Applies partial front braking when the rear brake is applied.
questions.answerC: Applies even braking for both the front and rear brakes when either is applied.
questions.answerD: Learns and remembers the approximate braking force used by the rider.
questions.explanation: An integrated braking system is a variant of a linked braking system. Partial front braking is applied whenever the rear brake is activated. Check your owner's manual for a detailed explanation of the braking system on your motorcycle.

questions.question: Of the following, which should you not do to improve your safety when riding at night?
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerC: Use your high beam headlight whenever possible.
questions.answerD: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: To ride safely at night, you should reduce your speed, use your high beam headlight when you are not riding near other vehicles, and increase your following distance. Take advantage of vehicles ahead of you to provide clues about the upcoming road. Their headlights may help to illuminate the road ahead and their taillights will bounce up and down if the vehicle is being driven over bumps on the road.

questions.question: When an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing upward, it means the operator:
questions.answerA: Plans to turn left.
questions.answerB: Is about to stop.
questions.answerC: Plans to turn right.
questions.answerD: Is about to slow down.
questions.explanation: Instead of mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing upward, it means the operator plans to turn right or change lanes to the right.

questions.question: When looking through a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn both your head and your shoulders to get a better look.
questions.answerB: Turn just your head, not your shoulders.
questions.answerC: Use only your mirrors.
questions.answerD: Only move your eyes, not your head.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: Riding directly alongside another vehicle is discouraged because:
questions.answerA: You may have a difficult time getting to a highway exit.
questions.answerB: You may be in the other vehicle’s blind spot.
questions.answerC: You may block the driver's view.
questions.answerD: It prevents other drivers from passing both of you.
questions.explanation: Riding alongside another vehicle is dangerous because you could be riding in the vehicle's blind spot. The driver may enter your lane without warning if they can't see you. The vehicle will also block your route of escape if a hazard arises.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerA: Just behind the leader.
questions.answerB: In front of the group.
questions.answerC: At the rear of the group.
questions.answerD: Beside the leader.
questions.explanation: In a group of motorcyclists, riders with less experience should be positioned toward the front of the group, just behind the leader. This will allow more experienced riders behind them to keep an eye on them.

questions.question: When riding at night you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerC: Use the vehicle in front of you to help see.
questions.answerD: Wear tinted glasses.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: In any crash, you have a better chance of avoiding serious injury if you do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Wear an approved helmet.
questions.answerB: Wear face or eye protection.
questions.answerC: Wear protective clothing.
questions.answerD: Have a windshield.
questions.explanation: You can reduce your risk of injury when riding a motorcycle by wearing an approved helmet, face or eye protection, and protective clothing.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, you should ride in:
questions.answerA: The left side of the lane.
questions.answerB: The center of the lane.
questions.answerC: The right side of the lane.
questions.answerD: Either the right or center portions of the lane.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. This lane position will provide you with the most effective view of the passing lane.

questions.question: Under Oregon law:
questions.answerA: Your motorcycle's headlight must be only between the hours of 7 p.m. and 7 a.m.
questions.answerB: Your motorcycle's headlight must be yellow in color.
questions.answerC: Your motorcycle's headlight must be on at all times when the motorcycle is being operated.
questions.answerD: Your motorcycle may have four lights on the front.
questions.explanation: Oregon law requires a motorcycle's headlight to be on at all times when the motorcycle is being operated. Using your headlight is the best way to ensure that other drivers will see your motorcycle.

questions.question: When braking, you should:
questions.answerA: First apply the front brake, then the rear.
questions.answerB: First apply the rear brake, then the front.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.answerD: Use brakes in any order.
questions.explanation: Both brakes should be used at the same time whenever you slow or stop.

questions.question: The front brake supplies how much of a motorcycle's stopping power?
questions.answerA: About one-quarter
questions.answerB: About one-half
questions.answerC: About three-quarters
questions.answerD: All the stopping power
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. It can provide three-fourths of the bike's total stopping power.

questions.question: You will ______ hear a tire going flat.
questions.answerA: Always
questions.answerB: Usually
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: Seldom
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists will seldom hear their tire go flat. Tire failure is more commonly indicated by a sudden change in handling.

questions.question: You should increase your following distance if:
questions.answerA: The pavement is dry.
questions.answerB: The pavement is wet.
questions.answerC: You can see through the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.answerD: The sun is out.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a larger following distance.

questions.question: When securing a load, you should place the load:
questions.answerA: As high as possible.
questions.answerB: As low as possible.
questions.answerC: On a sissy bar.
questions.answerD: Only on one side of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Secured loads should be low. Putting them too high up, such as on a sissy bar, can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and upset its balance. Loads should be as evenly distributed as possible on each side of the motorcycle to avoid pulling the bike to one side.

questions.question: Motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Do not have blind spots because of their small size.
questions.answerB: Have blind spots, but they are so small they should not cause concern.
questions.answerC: Have blind spots that should be routinely checked.
questions.answerD: Are too small to have blind spots.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like any other vehicle. Always turn your head to check your blind spot before changing lanes. Head checks should be a regular part of your scanning routine.

questions.question: If attempting to brake in a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake more gradually than you would on a straightaway.
questions.answerB: Brake as hard as you would on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: Wait until you are not in the curve to brake.
questions.answerD: Only use the rear brake.
questions.explanation: Because tires have less traction when a motorcycle is leaning than when it is upright, always try to position your motorcycle in an upright position before braking. If you must brake while in a curve, apply the brakes more smoothly and gradually than if your motorcycle was traveling on a straightaway.

questions.question: Engine braking:
questions.answerA: Is illegal.
questions.answerB: Is slowing down by turning the engine off.
questions.answerC: Is slowing down by downshifting.
questions.answerD: Is not encouraged because of the damage it does to the engine.
questions.explanation: Shifting to a lower gear produces an effect similar to applying the brakes. This is known as engine braking.

questions.question: When changing lanes, riders should:
questions.answerA: Rely only on their mirrors to identify other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Turn their head to look for traffic behind them.
questions.answerC: Not worry about other traffic.
questions.answerD: Slam on the brakes to allow any vehicles in their blind spot to pass.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle has blind spots just like any other vehicle. A rider must always turn their head to check for traffic before changing lanes.

questions.question: When someone follows you too closely, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerB: Not worry about them and just focus on the road in front of you.
questions.answerC: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder and let them pass.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to change lanes and let them pass you. Speeding up may cause them to tailgate you at a higher speed, only increasing the danger. Never ride on the shoulder of a road because drivers will never expect you to be there and may leave the road suddenly.

questions.question: A linked braking system:
questions.answerA: Connects the front and rear brakes, applying both brakes when either brake lever is applied.
questions.answerB: Connects the front brake to the gear shifter, applying the brake when the rider downshifts.
questions.answerC: Connects the rear brake to a foot control.
questions.answerD: Connects the rear brake to a switch on the handlebar.
questions.explanation: A linked braking system connects the front and rear brakes on a motorcycle. This system applies braking pressure to both brakes when either the front or rear lever is used. Check your owner's manual for a detailed explanation of the braking system on your motorcycle.

questions.question: Where is the gearshift lever located?
questions.answerA: In front of the left footrest
questions.answerB: In front of the right footrest
questions.answerC: On the left handgrip
questions.answerD: On the right handgrip
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever is located in front of the left footrest and is operated with the left foot.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to blend into traffic and not be noticed by other drivers.
questions.answerB: Not use turn signals unless you are traveling at night.
questions.answerC: Use your turn signals when changing lanes and making turns.
questions.answerD: Ride closely to the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, ensure that you are visible to others on the road. Communicate your intentions through your turn signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain an adequate space cushion, scan your path of travel 12 seconds ahead of your vehicle, and be prepared to act if any hazards arise.

questions.question: To swerve correctly:
questions.answerA: Shift your weight quickly.
questions.answerB: Turn the handlebars quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.explanation: To execute a swerve, press the handgrip on the side of your desired turn. Press on the opposite handgrip to return to your original direction after you are clear of the hazard.

questions.question: When looking for a protective jacket or pair of pants, you should look for:
questions.answerA: Items made of leather.
questions.answerB: Items made of polyester.
questions.answerC: Items made of light materials.
questions.answerD: Items that are darkly-colored.
questions.explanation: It is safest to wear long pants and a jacket to fully cover your arms and legs while riding. Clothing made of leather can provide the highest level of protection.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger or cargo:
questions.answerA: It may take less time to accelerate, but more time to stop.
questions.answerB: It may take more time to accelerate and stop.
questions.answerC: It may take more time to accelerate, but less time to stop.
questions.answerD: It may take less time to accelerate and stop.
questions.explanation: Because of the additional weight added by cargo or a passenger, motorcycles may take longer to accelerate and stop than they would if only transporting the operator.

questions.question: A larger cushion of space may not be necessary if:
questions.answerA: The pavement is slippery.
questions.answerB: You cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.answerC: Weather and traffic conditions are perfect.
questions.answerD: Traffic is heavy.
questions.explanation: Your following distance should be larger than usual when you are traveling under imperfect conditions. Increase your following distance if pavement is slippery, you can't see through the vehicle in front of you, or traffic is heavy.

questions.question: Increase your following distance:
questions.answerA: If the roadway is slippery.
questions.answerB: If there are only a few vehicles on the roadway.
questions.answerC: If the sun is shining.
questions.answerD: If drivers are following the speed limit.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up your following distance.

questions.question: Most motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Have only a front brake.
questions.answerB: Have only a rear brake.
questions.answerC: Have brakes in both the front and rear.
questions.answerD: Have three brakes: one in the front, one in the rear, and an emergency brake.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles generally have two brakes, one for the front wheel and one for the rear wheel.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection usually takes:
questions.answerA: A few minutes and should be done no more than once a month.
questions.answerB: A few minutes and should be done before every ride.
questions.answerC: Over an hour and should be performed by a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Over an hour and must only be done if you will be carrying a passenger.
questions.explanation: Conduct a thorough pre-ride inspection before every ride. It should usually take only a few minutes.

questions.question: Making eye contact with another driver:
questions.answerA: Guarantees that the other driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerB: Is not worth the effort it takes.
questions.answerC: Doesn’t mean that the driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: Means that the other driver knows you are there.
questions.explanation: You should never take eye contact with another driver as a guarantee that they will properly yield the right-of-way to you.
